Award.AwardTitle: Type 2: The Future of Ecosystems and Extremes: Using Diverse Environmental Data Sets in Support of Regional to Global Earth-System Models and Predictions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Our nation's natural and managed ecosystems are essential to public livelihood and its sustainable future. Extreme climate and weather events impose a substantial risk to ecosystem productivity, as such events are the most damaging and costly. Further increases in the frequency, strength, and/or duration of extreme events under altered environmental conditions may also result in irrecoverable damages to ecosystems. Therefore, it is of critical importance to comprehensively observe, understand, document, and predict ecosystems' response and resiliency to extreme environmental conditions and the extent to which irreversible thresholds may be crossed as a result of changes in the Earth's natural and human systems. Improved performance in predictive models is achieved only through observational evidence of ecosystem behavior under the full range of environmental conditions. The current suite of ecologic, meteorological, and hydrologic observations combined with the nation's next-generation National Ecologic Observation Network (NEON) allow an exciting opportunity to enable new analyses that comprehensively span the diverse types of ecosystems across our nation. This study undertakes coordinated calibration, evaluation, enhancement, and experimentation with a hierarchy of predictive tools that includes: models representing the field-scale mechanisms of ecosystems; a high-resolution regional ecosystem-climate model; as well as a global integrated assessment model of the linked earth-human systems. Through these, region-specific thresholds in the productivity, response, and resiliency of ecosystems governed by human-altered shifts in weather and climate extremes as well as land use, which pose severe implications for ecosystem services, will be identified.

The testing and evaluation of ecosystem models against the NEON observations will identify the critical model capabilities required to faithfully predict ecosystem response to extreme conditions. Under the auspice of potential climate and environmental change through the end of this century, projections with regional and global human-earth systems models will also allow for a risk-based assessment of ecologic change and resiliency. This is possible through the ability to run these models across the range of plausible human emissions and the climate/ecologic response. The atmospheric outputs of these regional ecosystem-climate projections could then also be used as boundary conditions for other detailed studies of regional climate impacts - such as air quality and water resources (quantity and quality). Overall, the scientific assessments and predictions from this study will enable local stakeholders as well as national and international policymakers to make more informed decisions regarding mitigation and adaptation strategies - particularly those that are relevant to the protection of natural and managed ecosystems threatened by extreme environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Extreme events are unavoidable, widespread, and ever-present within our environment. As society's impingements and interferences with the natural environment continue to increase, so will the risk of damage from extreme conditions and events. As we approach the midcentury with a global and modernized population expected to be over 9 billion people, we are therefore faced with growing and inexorable threats to public safety, natural and managed ecosystem resources, infrastructure, and societal livelihood.

However, for any action or decision to be made to prepare for this looming situation, we must make a prediction of the future might be, and therefore rely on model simulations that solve a set of "complex" equations that describe our environment.  For the case of extreme events and the ecosystem response, the equations in models either explain observed relationships, follow fundamental laws of nature, or in many cases - both. Yet in any of these cases, models are only as good as what observations can tell us and whether or not the behavior they are trying to simulate is correct. For extreme events, this poses a unique challenge in that, extreme events don't happen very often nor at the same location. While the rarity of these extreme events is advantageous for anything or anyone that has been a victim of the event, it presents a unique challenge for developing reliable models and prediction tools. Because the more often you observe an event, the more likely you are to understand that event and develop a model to replicate its behavior and therefore serve as a reliable prediction tool.  For extreme events, we therefore need a sustained system or network of observations to improve our models.

Given these considerations and with the deployment of the National Ecological Observation Network (NEON), our research has focused on the potential for NEON to provide the data necessary to make important strides in our ability to predict extreme events that pose a threat to natural and managed ecosystems. In order to do this, we collected existing data at measurement sites that closely resembled the (new) NEON sites - but more importantly - had observations that were taken over long periods of time, ideally at least 10 years and preferably more so that we had a better chance of these stations recording an "extreme" event or conditions. We also had to use a number of different models and methods to test against these observations. This was necessary because the family of models used for environmental prediction have many different uses, and therefore the equations that are contained in them will not be identical.  For this reason, we wanted to assess whether there were "critical" pieces within these models that had to be included to accurately simulate, and therefore predict, extreme events and the ecosystem responses to them.

For ecosystems - we found that one very important element of the model was that the representation of carbon and nitrogen storage was very important toward the accuracy of its response to an "extreme" event.  For our study, our focus was on droughts, and the evidence indicated that the carbon and nitrogen storage provided an important piece of "memory" about the ecosystems' past and whether it would respond one way or another to an extreme event. In this respect, another important aspect of the models' behavior was the description (or lack) of land-use legacy. Our model experiments indicated that the that for any ecosystem affected either by human activity (or use) in the past or a prolonged change in the climate that significantly altered its structure, could also have a strong effect to its response to an extreme event that occurs today - or in the future. Other work has also shown the importance of the snowpack as well as the vertical structure of the ecosystems' canopy to their behavior. 

At the climate scale - our research has also demonstrated that there exists a remarkable potential for machine-learning and big-data methods to improve our consensus of predictions.  Our analyses demonstrated and quantified that there are strong relationships - across the history of observations - that can be dissected between the occurrence of an extreme event at the "local" scale (i.e. at a field) and conditions the large-scale (i.e. weather systems).  The relationships - or "analogues" - can then be programmed to search within simulations of the future climate such as those from the IPCC.  We have shown that these "analogue" methods considerably strengthen the consensus of predicted trends in extreme event occurrence.

Overall - our study underscored and highlighted the critical importance of sustained, coordinated networks and platforms of observations. Models' predictions are only as reliable as the observations that provide understanding and verification of performance.  The scientific community must remain steadfast in these efforts and provide the information needed to act against growing environmental threats.
